Sentence.sentence: deprive colleges of the right to manage their facilitiesmake workers less motivated in performing dutiesrender a number of campus workers joblesslead to the privatization of campus facilitiesThe outsourcing plan is not yet finalized.
Workers' advocates have criticized Haslam's plan, saying it would mean some campus workers would lose their jobs or benefits.
The company pledged to cut 600 back-office positions, though some 150 workers in those roles would be reassigned to other jobs.
To alert American workers to the urgency for adaptation.
This isn't a battle between garment workers and greedy bosses.
There's work to be done, but workers aren't ready to do it—they're in the wrong places, or they have the wrong skills.
The fact is job openings have plunged in every major sector, while the number of workers forced into parttime employment in almost all industries has soared.
Nationwide training of workers.
A few years later, a large defense buildup finally provided a fiscal stimulus adequate to the economy's needs—and suddenly industry was eager to employ those unadaptable and untrained workers.
With technology everywhere in our life, it has become virtually impossible for most workers to keep a balance  between work and life.
These less- stressed workers gained an average of 62 minutes per week of productivity.
The U.S. is also the only advanced economy that does not guarantee workers paid vacation time, and it's  one of only two countries in the world that does not offer guaranteed paid maternity leave.
Seven in 10 workers say they struggle to maintain work-life balance.
Science has shown a clear correlation between high stress levels in workers and absenteeism ( ' ,  旷工 ), reduced  productivity, disengagement and high turnover.
It's not only unsustainable for workers, but also for the companies that employ them.
In  a  competitive  work  environment,  employers  are  able  to  use  technology  to  demand more from their employees rather than motivating workers with flexibility that benefits them.
But that isn't why the government—under pressure from cancer charities, health workers and the Labour party—has agreed to legislate for standardised packaging.

83% of workers say they're stressed about  their jobs, nearly 50% say work-related stress is interfering with their sleep, and 60% use their smartphones  to check in with work outside of normal working hours.
Wherever needed, social workers come to help.
We hope you enjoy the series about how you can make a difference by becoming a social worker.
Today we are going to be talking about becoming a social worker.
Throughout these series, you will learn more about the profession, the necessary steps to get a social work degree, the rich history of social work and many ways that social workers help others.
There are more than 600,000 professional social workers in the country, and we all either have a bachelor’s degree, a master’s degree or a Ph D in social work.
There are more clinically trained social workers than clinically trained psychiatrists, psychologists and psychiatric nurses combined.
The National Association of Social Workers represents nearly 145,000 social workers across the country.

Stacy is going to walk you through the step-by-step process of becoming a social worker and Mill will tell you about the range of options you have once you get your social work degree, as well as the high standards of responsibility the social workers must adhere to.
Later in these series, you will hear from Stacy Collins and Mill Wilson, fellow social workers at the National Association of Social Workers.
I’m a social worker, a lobbyist and a special assistant to the executive director at the National Association of Social Workers.
In thousands of ways, social workers help other people—people from every age, every background across the country.
One needs the designers, and perhaps the regulators, before the builders and operators, and each group of workers in training has to know there is work waiting beyond graduation.
And not only do our prospective new energy workers have to be trained, they have to be trained in the right sequence.
Here is the most malignant threat to our personal freedom, particularly as the balance of power in the workplace has been shifted so dramatically from worker to boss.
Sentence.come: 2019年12月六级真题（第二套）听力 Section C

Sentence.sentence: workers received on the job.

The findings of a research institution have consistently shown that workers in all countries can be trained on the job to achieve radical higher productivity and, as a result, radically higher standards of living.

More recently, while examining housing construction, the researchers discovered that illiterate, non-English- speaking Mexican workers in Houston, Texas, consistently met best-practice labor productivity standards despite the complexity of the building industry’s work.
When Hoffa’s Teamsters were in their prime in 1960, only one in ten American government workers belonged to a union; now 36% do.
The only American public-sector workers who earn well above $250,000 a year are university sports coaches and the president of the United States.
In Britain, more than half of public-sector workers but only about 15% of private-sector ones are unionized.
A quarter of America’s public-sector workers have a university degree.
Optimists point out that technological upheaval has benefited workers in the past.
Likewise,automation should eventually boost productivity, stimulate demand by driving down prices, and free workers from hard, boring work.
But policies to help workers adapt will be indispensable.
But in the medium term,middle-class workers may need a lot of help adjusting.
One survey found that bureaucratic delays led the average H-2A worker to arrive on the job 22 days late.

工人,职工,工匠,苦力,奴仆

entry.def: A particular kind of worker does the kind of work mentioned.

example.ex: The society was looking for a capable research worker.
example.tran: 该协会在物色一位有能力的研究人员。

entry.def: Workers are people who are employed in industry or business and who are not managers.

example.ex: Wages have been frozen and workers laid off.
...a call for the workers of the world to unite...
example.tran: 呼吁全世界工人团结起来的号召

entry.def: You can use worker to say how well or badly someone works.

example.ex: He is a hard worker and a skilled gardener...
example.tran: 他工作很努力，对园艺很在行。

example.ex: A first-class worker, she operated the difficult Jacquard looms.
example.tran: 她技艺高超，操作着复杂的提花织布机。

means.word_mean: 1. a person who works at a specific occupation;
2. a member of the working class (not necessarily employed);
3. sterile member of a colony of social insects that forages for food and cares for the larvae
4. a person who acts and gets things done;

sentences.cn: 一家研究机构的研究成果一致证明，所有国家的工人都可以通过在职培训从根本上提高生产力，从而大幅度提高生活水平。
sentences.en: The findings of a research institution have consistently shown that workers in all countries can be trained on the job to achieve radical higher productivity and, as a result, radically higher standards of living.

sentences.cn: 乐观主义者指出，以往的技术剧变曾使工人获益。
sentences.en: Optimists point out that technological upheaval has benefited workers in the past.

sentences.cn: 同样，自动化会最终提高生产效率，通过压低价格来刺激消费需求，并将工人从乏味辛苦的工作中解放出来。
sentences.en: Likewise, automation should eventually boost productivity, stimulate demand by driving down prices, and free workers from hard, boring work.

sentences.cn: 过去，只要有个一般的手艺，做份普通的工作，工人的生活就过得还凑合。
sentences.en: In the past, workers with average skills, doing an average job, could earn an average lifestyle.

sentences.cn: 但我们确信无疑的是，全球化和信息技术革命每前进一步，最佳岗位都会要求工人接受更多、更优质的教育，从而使他们从常人中脱颖而出。
sentences.en: But the one thing we know for sure is that with each advance in globalization and the I.T. revolution, the best jobs will require workers to have more and better education to make themselves above average.

sentences.cn: 哈格尔说，这就是我们在美国工人背上贴上巨大的攻打标靶的方式。
sentences.en: That is how we have put a giant target sign on the backs of American workers, Hagel says.

sentences.cn: 全国各地的工厂老板现在正努力应对一个新的挑战:他们可能最终只能佣到很少而不是大量的工人。
sentences.en: Across the country, factory owners are now grappling with a new challenge: instead of having too many workers, they may end up with too few.

sentences.cn: 但对于工厂老板来说,所有这些意味着他们将对工人展开激烈的争夺,并面临新金上涨的压力
sentences.en: For factory owners, it all adds up to staff competition for workers —and upward pressure no wages.

sentences.cn: 但是为了争取这些青年工人,制造商必频清除另一个主要障:即经历过自大萧条以来最糟的美国经济低迷时期的父母,这些父母告诉他们要远离工厂。
sentences.en: But to win over these young workers, manufacturers have to clear another major hurdle: parents, who lived through the worst US economic downturn since the Great Depression, telling them to avoid the factory.

sentences.cn: 但仅有44%的工人接受过足够的培训。
sentences.en: But only 44 percent of workers are adequately trained

sentences.cn: 在需要建筑者和操作员之前，可能最先需要一位设计师或管理者，而且每一组接受培训的工人都需要了解在毕业之后有工作等着他们。
sentences.en: One needs the designers, and perhaps the  regulators , before the builders and operators, and each group of workers in training has to know there is work waiting beyond graduation.

sentences.en: The U.S. is also the only  advanced  economy  that  does  not  guarantee  workers  paid vacation  time,  and  it’s  one  of  only  two  countries  in  the  world that does not offer guaranteed paid maternity leave
sentences.from: 16年12月六级真题（第一套）| 阅读

sentences.cn: 在充满竞争的工作环境下，雇主们得以利用技术之便对员工提出更多要求，而不是通过提供有利于员工的灵活工作制度来鼓励他们。
sentences.en: In a competitive work environment, employers are  able  to  use  technology  to  demand  more  from  their  employees rather than motivating workers with flexibility that benefits them.

sentences.en: If you want something to be done, then their staff do not have so much incentive to help you because he’s a worker for the government.
sentences.from: 16年6月六级真题（第二套）| 听力

sentences.cn: 今天，时区变得越来越没有意义，很少有公司机构中午会为了午餐关门休息，而且城市里越来越糟糕的交通情况意味着员工们来不及回家，然后再回来上班。
sentences.en: Today,  when  time  zones  have  less  and  less  meaning, there is little tolerance for offices ’  closing for lunch,  and  worsening  traffic  in  cities  means  workers  can’t  make  it  home and back fast enough anyway.
